Chimica Ind. e dei Materiali, Univ. Bologna, V.le Risorgimento 4, 40136 Bologna, Italy Received 2 August 1994; revised 8 December 1994; accepted 8 December 1994 Abstract The changes that take place in a vanadium antimonate catalyst during catalytic propane ammoxi- dation were studied by transient reactivity experiments and infrared spectroscopy. The investigation was focused on both the change in catalytic behaviour of a fresh sample and the change in reactivity with stepwise increases in the concentration of one or more reagents while maintaining the concen- tration of the other reactants constant. The results obtained show that two main types of modifications are present: ( 1 ) A change in the reactivity from the fresh to the activated samples due to the surface formation of a VSbO4 phase by reaction of vanadium and antimony oxides that have not reacted during calcination; this modification leads to formation of carbon oxides and a decrease in the rate of propane depletion as well as a considerable increase in the rate of acrylonitrile formation. (2) A change in the reactivity of the activated sample which is a function of the redox characteristics of the reagent mixture; this modification does not change the rate of propane depletion, but rather only results in differences in the relative selectivity to products. The results also show that (i) in the steady state, the activated catalyst is partially reduced in comparison with the same sample after treatment with oxygen and (ii) the rate of acrylonitrile formation is lower. Infrared results confirm the formation of oxygen vacancies in the catalyst upon interaction with ammonia and propene as well as the presence of these defects in the sample after the catalytic tests. Keywords: Acrylonitrile; Propane ammoxidation; Surface reactivity; Vanadium antimonate 1. Introduction The direct synthesis of acrylonitrile from propane rather than from propene has drawn considerable attention recently due to the economic advantages in substitut- ing an alkane for an alkene feedstock. The best performances for this reaction have been obtained with vanadium antimonate-based catalysts and several patents have 0926-860X/95/$09.50 1995 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved SSDI O926-860 X ( 94 ) 00280-0 318 G. Centi, S. Perathoner /Applied Catalysis A: General 124 (1995) 317-337 been published on the use of these catalysts for the synthesis of acrylonitrile from propane ( [ 1--4] and references therein]. Less information, on the other hand, is available on the characterization of the surface and structural characteristics of vanadium antimonate-based catalysts [ 5-11 ] and especially on the correlation with their catalytic behaviour in the ammoxidation of propane to acrylonitrile. It has been observed [ 4-6 ], however, that (i) both vanadium and antimony on the surface of the catalyst are reduced during the catalytic tests, (ii) severe reaction conditions (high temperature, high concentrations of propane and ammonia and a low oxygen concentration) may lead to a too strong reduction of the catalyst with decomposition of the vanadium antimonate phase and an irreversible deactivation of the catalyst, (iii) vanadium and antimony oxide may also react during the catalytic reaction to reform the VSbO4 phase, depending on the reaction conditions and (iv) the amount of an amorphous V5 + oxide phase spread on the surface of vanadium antimonate crystals, rate of the side reaction of ammonia oxidation to nitrogen and lowering of the selectivity to acrylonitrile are interrelated. In addition, it is reported in some patents that an activation procedure during catalytic propane ammoxidation leads to an improvement in the yield to acrylonitrile [ 12]. It is clear, therefore, that during catalytic propane ammoxidation significant changes occur in both the bulk and surface of the vanadium antimonate-based catalysts. The nature of these changes and their relationships with the observed modifications of the surface reactivity can give useful information on the nature of the active sites and on the key properties of the catalyst necessary for the improve- ment of the catalytic behaviour of vanadium antimonate catalysts for propane ammoxidation. Characterization data on the changes in the bulk and surface properties of vana- dium antimonate catalysts after catalytic tests have been previously reported [ 3- 6]. The authors of these studies also pointed out, however, that the analysis alone of the catalysts after the catalytic tests does not give sufficient information on the nature of the active sites, because some of the observed changes may be due only to side effects not relevant for the catalytic activity. In addition, the combination of the kinetic data [ 1,2] and characterization results [ 3-6] suggests that the selec- tivity to acrylonitrile is considerably affected by the nature of the redox surface changes occurring during the catalytic reaction. The objective of the research reported here was to analyze the change in the surface reactivity of a vanadium antimonate catalyst due to its modifications during the catalytic reaction. The method used for this purpose was to follow in a real- time analysis the modifications in the catalytic behaviour of a vanadium antimonate catalyst with stepwise increases in the concentration of one or more reagents while maintaining the other concentrations constant. In addition, infrared analysis to characterize the nature of the changes in the catalyst when put in contact at high temperature with propane and ammonia were also carded out in order to obtain a better understanding of the relationships between the nature of the changes in the catalyst and the modifications in the surface reactivity in propane ammoxidation. G. Centi, S. Perathoner / Applied Catalysis A: General 124 (1995) 317-337 319 An unsupported vanadium antimonate catalyst with a V:Sb molar ratio of 1:5 was used in these tests, because the analysis of the catalytic behaviour as a function of the V:Sb ratio has shown that this excess of antimony is necessary to obtain a good selectivity to acrylonitrile from propane [ 3-6], in agreement with patent indica- tions. 2. Experimental V-Sb oxides were prepared according to patent indications ( [ 1--4] and refer- ences therein) by a slurry method which involved refluxing for at least 8 h (usually 24 h) an aqueous solution containing NH4VO3 and Sb203 (in such a ratio as to obtain a Sb/V atomic ratio of 5.0) followed by evaporation of the solvent in a rotavapor and drying at 100 overnight. The resulting solid was then heat treated at 350 for 4 h followed by a further step at 650 (6 h) (after intermediate grinding and mixing of the sample) in the presence of air. Further details on the method of preparation of these samples and on their characterization have been reported previously [4,6]. The catalytic activity of these samples under steady- state conditions has also been previously reported [5]. Hereinafter reference to fresh samples indicates those samples which have undergone the calcination step, whereas activated samples refer to samples which have been subjected to catalytic tests in propane ammoxidation for at least 24 h of time-on-stream. Stepwise transient catalytic studies were carried out in an apparatus with an on- line VG SX200 mass quadrupole apparatus equipped with a double turbomolecular vacuum pump system in order to enhance the instrumental time-response to changes in the concentrations. The single gas (He, 02, NH3, C3H8), stored in cylinders in already calibrated mixtures in helium, was sent to a quick-switch four-way valve after regulation of the flow to generate the stepwise changes in the concentration of one or more reagents while maintaining the other concentrations constant. This was realized by substituting an independent flow of helium with that of an equal flow of helium containing the desired reagents. In this way it was possible to maintain the catalyst in a continuous flow of one or more reagents while inducing at selected times a stepwise change in the concentrations of one or more of the other reagents. Due to the slow time-response of the apparatus to stepwise changes in the ammonia concentration, the concentrations of oxygen and C3 were usually changed in this way, whereas the concentration of ammonia, when present, was maintained constant. The time-resolved change in the reactor outlet concentration of the reagents or reaction products was monitored using a mass quadrupole apparatus and the results were compared with those of the same experiments which were carried out using, in place of the catalyst, an equivalent volume of quartz microspheres having the same mean diameter as that of the catalyst particles. A quartz catalytic reactor with reduced dead volume was used to reduce the possible presence of a homogeneous 320 G. Centi, S. Perathoner / Applied Catalysis A: General 124 (1995) 317-337 reaction. In addition, the lines connecting the outlet of the reactor to the head of the mass quadrupole apparatus were maintained at around 160 in order to avoid condensation of the products. The quantification of the concentration of the various components in the inlet and outlet stream of the reactor was obtained by calibration of the mass quadrupole response using calibrated mixtures in helium of the single components of the feed. For acrylonitrile, calibrated amounts of the liquid were introduced in a helium flow by means of an infusion pump. Fluctuations in the operating pressure of the mass quadrupole detector were compensated for by using the helium pressure as an internal standard. The mass quadrupole data were elab- orated and corrected to take into account the possible presence of multiple frag- mentations on a single mass intensity. For example, 36% of the intensity of mass 29 (propane) and 15 % of the intensity of mass 42 (propene) were subtracted from the intensity of mass 44 (carbon dioxide). For propene (mass 42), 5% of the intensity of mass 29 (propane) was subtracted and for ammonia (mass 17), 25% of the intensity of mass 18 (water) was subtracted. The following mass intensities were simultaneously followed for the various compounds: mass 4 for helium, mass 17 for ammonia, mass 18 for water, mass 28 for N2 + CO, mass 29 for C3H8, mass 32 for 02, mass 42 for C3H6, mass 44 for CO2 and mass 53 for acrylonitrile. Experiments were usually done with 1.0 g of catalyst consisting of grains 0.1- 0.2 mm in diameter; the total flow-rate was 6 1 h-~ and the reaction temperature was 520. The concentration of propane in the feed was 2.7% with an O2/propane molar ratio of 2 and an NH3/propane molar ratio of 1, unless otherwise indicated. The quartz reactor inlet diameter was 10 mm in order to reduce the catalyst bed length, thus reducing possible readsorption phenomena. The usual tests and cal- culations were also done, in order to verify the absence of inter- and intra-phase mass diffusional limitations under our experimental conditions, whereas heat trans- fer limitations were found to be negligible. An axial thermocouple inserted in the catalytic bed made it possible to determine the catalyst bed temperature and to verify the absence of hot-spot phenomena. Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra (resolution 2 cm-l) were recorded with a Perkin-Elmer 1750 instrument in a quartz cell connected to grease-free evacuation and gas manipulation lines. The self-supporting disk technique was used. Before recording the spectra, the samples were first evacuated at 500 for 3 h. 3. Results 3.1. Transient reactivity of the fresh sample Reported in Fig. 1 is the change in the surface reactivity of the flesh vanadium antimonate sample (V:Sb = 1:5) when the feed to the reactor was switched from a helium flow to a flow containing propane, oxygen and ammonia. The choice of these reagent concentrations was based on the previous results of similar catalytic tests [3-5]; the reaction temperature (520) that was used in all the experiments was also chosen on the basis of the results of these previous studies. The catalytic behaviour changed considerably during the first five minutes of time-on-stream and then remained essentially stable. The following changes were observed during the period before steady-state behaviour was reached: ( 1 ) The conversion of all reagents (propane, ammonia and oxygen) progressively decreased with the most significant change occurring in the first 5 min of time- on-stream. (2) The formation of carbon oxides and nitrogen, the latter deriving from the side reaction of oxidation of ammonia, progressively decreased up to the time that steady-state behaviour was reached; however, in the steady state, a significant part of ammonia conversion was still due to its oxidation to nitrogen. (3) The formation of acrylonitrile (hereinafter referred to as ACN) and propene was initially low and then increased progressively with increasing time-on- stream. The results of the time-on-stream behaviour (Fig. 1 ) clearly indicate that there is a parallel decrease in both the formation of carbon oxides and in the side reaction of ammonia oxidation to nitrogen during the first minutes in contact with the 322 G. Centi, S. Perathoner /Applied Catalysis A: General 124 (1995)317-337 feedstock. This initial modification of the surface reactivity leads to a significant increase in the yield and selectivity to ACN and propene. It is interesting to note that parallel to the decrease in the formation of carbon oxides there is also a decrease in propane conversion indicating that the modification of the surface reactivity during the catalytic reactions leads to a specific inhibition of sites able to unselec- tively oxidize propane to carbon oxides. It is also worth noting that characterization data on vanadium antimonate catalysts after propane ammoxidation [5] show a more rapid reduction of vanadium in comparison to antimony and in comparison with structural changes detected in the catalyst after long time-on-stream. The rapid change in the catalytic behaviour in the first 5 min of time-on-stream (Fig. 1 ) may be attributed to the reduction of surface V5 + sites present on VSbO4 and Sb204 crystals [5]. The total amount of vanadium in the catalyst in these tests was about 1.2- 10-3 mol, around 1% of which may be estimated to be present on the surface, taking into consideration the low surface area of the sample (about 7 m2 g ~ ) and the unit cell dimensions. The total number of moles converted in 5 min of ammonia and C3H8 is about 4- 10-4, but it should be remembered that gaseous oxygen is present. The rapid change in the surface reactivity and the number of moles converted are thus in agreement with the hypothesis that the initial reduction of surface V5 + sites is responsible for the observed change in the surface reactivity. 3.2. Effect of oxygen The transient response to stepwise changes in the concentration of oxygen, while maintaining the propane and ammonia concentration constant, is shown in Fig. 2. For these tests an actit,ated vanadium antimonate sample with a Sb:V ratio of 5 was used in order to characterize the effect of oxygen on a catalyst already condi- tioned in the catalytic reaction. While the formation of carbon oxides rapidly reached a constant value, the formation of propene clearly showed an initial maximum which then decreased to a constant value in about 15 min. The formation of acrylonitrile increased up to a constant value. These tests were carried out with a lower concentration of hydro- carbon (0.8%), but an analogous ammonia to propane ratio, in comparison with the tests shown in Fig. 1, because using this reduced concentration made it possible to observe the change in the formation of the products more clearly. This is also the reason why the formation of ACN in these tests is lower. Oxygen was initially consumed in a large amount in these tests, as shown by the difference between the oxygen response in the absence of the catalyst (dotted line) and in the presence of the catalyst. At the steady state, the difference in oxygen concentrations corresponds to the oxygen consumed in the propane and ammonia oxidation, but the initial large consumption of oxygen cannot be explained on the basis of the oxygen incorporated in the reaction products. This amount, on the basis of the estimated amount of surface vanadium sites discussed above, suggests that in the preliminary phase in the absence of gaseous oxygen not only vanadium is reduced, but also antimony. This is confirmed by the fact that the infrared spectrum and X-ray diffraction patterns of the catalyst after the treatment with ammonia and propane do not indicate bulk modifications or changes in the phase composition (presence of VSbO4 and t~-Sb204 phases), as expected in the hypothesis that all the oxygen incorporated upon admission of oxygen is required for the reoxidation of vanadium. In addition, the reduction of both vanadium and antimony is in agreement with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy results [4,5,13] which indicate the reduction of V5 to V4 + and Sb5 to Sb3 + on the surface of the catalyst after catalytic tests of propane ammoxidation. The concentration of gaseous oxygen, however, has a marked influence on the selectivity to acrylonitrile and to propene. This is shown in Fig. 3 which summarizes the results obtained using a variable concentration of oxygen in the feed, while maintaining the propane and oxygen concentration constant. The maximum selec- tivity to acrylonitrile was obtained when the outlet concentration of oxygen was low (around 0.5%). For higher concentrations of oxygen, the formation of carbon oxides was higher, whereas for lower concentrations of oxygen the formation of carbon oxides was low but that of propene increased. These data provide further evidence that propene is the intermediate to acrylonitrile [ 1-3] and that the con- centration of oxygen has a considerable effect on the selectivity to acrylonitrile 324 G. Effect of a change in the propane and ammonia concentration Reported in Fig. 4 is the response to stepwise changes in the concentration of propane in a flow of oxygen and ammonia in helium, whereas Fig. 5 shows similar results obtained for stepwise changes in the concentration of both propane and ammonia in a flow of oxygen in helium. Similarly to the tests reported in Figs. 2 and 3, an activated vanadium antimonate sample with a Sb:V ratio of 5 was used for these experiments. Similar results were obtained both in the presence and absence of ammonia during the initial pretreatment (up to time zero in the figures; the usual pretreatment time was 5-10 min). In both cases the steady-state activity was reached in about 10 min and the formation of carbon oxides and acrylonitrile decreased after the initial rapid increase due to the introduction of propane in the feed. The formation of propene instead increased up to the steady-state value. The similar time-response for acrylonitrile formation indicates that either the surface modification due to the formation of sites containing nitrogen (M=NH sites, for example, where M = V or Sb [ 14-16] ) is much faster than that observable in these experiments or that it does not occur. Perathoner / Applied Catalysis A: General 124 (1995) 317-337 the data shown in this work, but the second hypothesis is more consistent with the observation of the higher initial activity of the catalyst towards acrylonitrile syn- thesis when ammonia is absent during the pretreatment (Fig. 5). The oxidation of ammonia to nitrogen in the absence of propane is clearly shown in Fig. 4. However, notwithstanding the presence of this reducing agent during the pretreatment, the time-response for carbon dioxide and ACN formation is very similar to that in the absence of ammonia during pretreatment. This shows that any possible modifications of the surface of the catalyst due to the side reaction of ammonia oxidation are not relevant for the surface reactivity of the catalyst in propane ammoxidation, at least using the reagent concentrations employed for the tests in Fig. 4. In contrast, a significant change in the surface reactivity is shown in the first 10 min in the presence of propane both with and without ammonia present during the pretreatment. These results show that probably the nature of the sites responsible for the side reaction of the oxidation of ammonia to acrylonitrile is different from that of the sites responsible for the synthesis of acrylonitrile. Tentatively, the change in the activity after introduction of propane may be attributed to a partial reduction of Sb5 + to Sb3 which in turn is responsible for the change in the selectivity. Inter- estingly, the change in the selectivity of this activated sample does not correspond to a change in the rate of propane depletion, differently from the case of the tests with the fresh sample (compare Figs. 4 and 5 with Fig. 1 ). Two different types of changes in the surface reactivity were thus observed when the catalyst was put in contact with the feedstock for propane ammoxidation: ( 1 ) A change in the reactivity of the fresh sample which leads to an inhibition of a parallel reaction of propane oxidation to carbon oxides, a decrease in the rate of propane depletion and an increase in the formation of acrylonitrile. (2) A change in the reactivity of the activated sample, previously pretreated in the presence of oxygen or oxygen plus ammonia in helium, which does not cor- respond to a change in the rate of propane depletion, but only to a change in the selectivity with a decrease in the rate of acrylonitrile formation and increase in the formation of the intermediate propene. The decrease in the formation of carbon oxides in this case is probably due to a decrease in the consecutive conversion to carbon oxides of an adsorbed intermediate such as propene. It is reasonable to tentatively attribute these different changes in the surface reactivity of vanadium antimonate catalysts to the reduction of surface V5 sites and formation of the active VSbO4 species in the former case and to the partial reduction of Sb5to Sb3+ in the latter case. The reoxidation of the reduced antimony depends on the reaction conditions and specific characteristics of the catalyst, but these results suggest that the selectivity and rate of formation of acrylonitrile in the steady state depends on the rate of reoxidation of reduced antimony sites. The rate of propane depletion, however, does not depend on this factor, suggesting that it is instead related to the presence and valence state of the vanadium sites. G. Centi, S. Relationship between reoxidation of the catalyst and formation of acrylonitrile The previous results show that the activated catalyst treated in the presence of oxygen is partially reduced by the interaction with propane and ammonia in the presence of oxygen which in turn leads to a lowering of the rate of acrylonitrile formation. This problem was further investigated in transient experiments where the oxygen feed in a flow of propane and ammonia in helium was switched to an equal flow of only helium for a calibrated time, returning then to the initial condi- tions. Reported in Fig. 6 is an example of these experiments, whereas Fig. 7 summarizes the time-response of the formation of acrylonitrile after reintroduction of the oxygen feed that was suspended for different times (called time of prered- uction, since oxygen in the feed was absent). Immediately after the oxygen was stopped, a rapid increase in the formation of acrylonitrile was observed (see inset in Fig. 6), but then the formation of ACN decreases quickly. A similar behaviour is observed for propene formation, even though the decrease in the rate of formation of this product is slower than that of ACN. The formation of carbon oxides, on the other hand, immediately decreases. These results suggest that after removing gaseous oxygen, the catalyst lost its activity towards acrylonitrile synthesis in less than 5 min, whereas in the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane to propene the catalyst activity remains slightly longer. The initial increase in the formation of ACN and propene after the oxygen flow was stopped, in contrast to that observed for carbon dioxide formation, furthermore indicates that probably in the presence of gaseous oxygen the rate of the consecutive oxidation of these products to carbon oxides is higher. These results thus indicate that the structural oxygens of vanadium antimonate catalysts are able to transform propane to propene and acrylonitrile and in the absence of gaseous oxygen the catalyst is more selective, but the amount of struc- tural oxygens for this reaction is limited and the catalyst rapidly loses its activity. However, these data also indicate that the catalyst is reduced during the interaction with propane and ammonia in the absence of oxygen. After reintroduction of oxygen in the feed (Fig. 6), the catalyst takes some time to reach steady-state activity. This time is shorter for propene and longer for acrylonitrile and carbon dioxide. In particular, for acrylonitrile formation (Fig. 7) the time of prereduction in the flow of propane and ammonia in helium is propor- tional to the time required to reach the steady-state formation of acrylonitfile. In the case of the longer prereduction time, a significantly longer delay in reaching the steady-state value in the outlet oxygen concentration is also noted (Fig. 7) indicating that initially inlet oxygen is used for the reoxidation of the reduced catalyst. It is also worth noting that in these tests (prereduction time of 10 800 s) the formation of ACN appears only after oxygen starts to be detected in the outlet stream. Fig. 7. Discussion Transient catalytic studies of the change in the surface reactivity of vanadium antimonate catalyst during the propane ammoxidation reaction show the presence of two main types of modifications: ( 1 ) A change in the reactivity of the fresh sample which leads to the inhibition of a parallel reaction of propane oxidation to carbon oxides, a decrease in the rate of propane depletion and an increase in the formation of acrylonitrile. (2) A change in the reactivity of the activated sample, when prereduced, which does not lead to a change in the rate of propane depletion, but rather only results in changes in the selectivity with a decrease in the rate of acrylonitrile formation and an increase in the formation of the intermediate propene. G. Centi, S. Perathoner/Applied Catalysis A: General 124 (1995) 317-337 335 The first modification of the surface reactivity is reasonably due to the reaction between vanadium and antimony on the surface of the catalyst to form the VSbO4 active phase. It has been observed [4,6], in fact, that the formation of this phase after the stage of calcination is incomplete [25 ], especially on the surface of the catalyst [ 5 ], because the formation of this phase requires the presence of antimony in the oxidized state (Sb5 + ) and vanadium in the reduced state (V3 + and V4 + ). The latter, however, especially on the surface during calcination is rapidly oxidized limiting the formation of the vanadium antimonate phase on the surface in contrast to what occurs in the bulk of the sample. The presence of both reducing agents (propane and ammonia) and oxygen in the feedstock for propane ammoxidation, however, favours the formation of the VSbO4 phase on the surface. This explains the change in the catalytic behaviour observed during the first 1-2 h of time-on- stream to which corresponds an increase in the rate of synthesis of acrylonitrile and a decrease in the rate of the parallel side reaction to carbon oxides. The inhibition of this side reaction also explains the decrease in the conversion of propane. The infrared results of Fig. 12 (comparison of IR spectra of the fresh and acti~,ated sample) further support this interpretation. The second type of modification, on the other hand, is related to the reversible redox reaction which occurs during the catalytic reaction. The results obtained (Figs. 2 and 7), show clearly that in the absence of oxygen the catalyst is reduced and only when oxygen reoxidizes the catalyst is there an increase in the rate of acrylonitrile formation. On the other hand, it also was found (Fig. 5) that the rate of acrylonitrile formation, after interaction of the catalyst with only oxygen, decreases down to the steady-state value. This indicates that under steady-state conditions the rate of synthesis of acrylonitrile is controlled by the rate of reoxi- dation of reduced sites, at least for the undoped vanadium antimonate catalyst used in these tests. Infrared results (Figs. 9 and 10) indicate the reduction of the catalyst upon interaction with ammonia and/or hydrocarbon. Furthermore, Fig. 10 shows that when SbzO4 is present together with a rutile vanadium antimonate phase, the extend of the surface reduction is probably lower. The reduction of Sb5 + to Sb3 + during the reaction is also evidenced by IR. The redox change in these sites during the catalytic reaction is probably responsible for the modification of the selectivity observed in Figs. 2, 4 and 5. The role of vanadium for the step from propene to ACN is probably that of enhancing the rate of reoxidation of reduced antimony, as suggested from quantitative interpretation of the data reported in Fig. 7. However, by analogy with the mechanism of alkane oxidation on (VO)2P207 catalysts [ 26] it is reasonable that vanadium also plays a role in the first step of oxidative dehy- drogenation of propane. The selectivity to acrylonitrile does not depend only on the presence of these Sb5 +-O sites, but also depends on the rate of the consecutive reactions to carbon oxides. These reactions in turn depend largely on the concentration of gaseous oxygen (Figs. 3 and 6). Gaseous oxygen is also involved in the reoxidation of reduced antimony sites; in addition, previous data show that the rate of acrylonitrile 336 G. Centi, S. Perathoner / Applied Catalysis A: General 124 (1995) 317-337 formation is controlled by this rate of reoxidation. Due to these two opposite effects, the selectivity to acrylonitrile thus passes through a maximum as a function of the oxygen concentration (Fig. 3). Kinetic data are in agreement with this conclusion [ 1-3 ]. The results of Fig. 5 indicate furthermore that the rate of the consecutive transformation to carbon oxides of the intermediate propene is higher than that for the formation of acrylonitrile. For this reason, a quick transformation of this inter- mediate to acrylonitrile is necessary in order to enhance the overall selectivity (propene + acrylonitrile). It should be noted that infrared results (Fig. 9) and ammonia stepwise transient reactivity studies (Fig. 5) suggest that the nature of the sites involved in the mechanism of propene transformation to acrylonitrile are not consistent with the hypothesis reported in the literature that the active sites are M=NH (where M = V or Sb) groups on the surface of the catalyst. This hypothesis has been extensively reported, even though not definitively proven, for the mechanism of acrylonitrile synthesis from propene over bismuth molybdate or iron antimonate catalysts ( [ 16,27,28] and references therein). The present data, on the other hand, are more consistent with a mechanism of oxygen insertion on the intermediate propene (reasonably activated in the allylic form) and consecutive reaction with ammonia of this oxidized intermediate. This is in agreement with the mechanism of acrylo- nitrile synthesis from propane over (VO) 2P207 catalyst [ 29 ] (a reaction mecha- nism involving the reaction between an adsorbed acrylate species and ammonium ions) and also agrees with previous suggestions on the mechanism of acrylonitrile synthesis of various metal oxide catalysts [24]. More detailed studies, however, are necessary to clarify the reaction mechanism. Infrared results also indicate that surface defects are created during the catalytic reaction. In agreement, the characterization of similar catalysts has shown that oxygen vacancies are probably present after propane ammoxidation [6]; these vacancies are stabilized by the VSbO4 rutile matrix because a mixed valence structure, containing V3 V4 +, Sb3 + and Sb5 + in variable composition, is possible due to similar ionic radii [6]. A relatively large number of oxygen vacancies can thus be stabilized in this structure. The presence of Sb204 crystallites together with the rutile phase apparently limits the formation of these vacancies (Fig. 10). The promotion effect of an excess of antimony over the selectivity to acrylonitrile from propane [5] may be tentatively attributed to this effect, because oxygen vacancies may lead to unselective forms of activated oxygen adspecies responsible of the enhanced rate of oxidation to carbon oxides. It also should be pointed out that the results reported in Fig. 8 show that a lower number of structural oxygens are incorporated in the reaction products in propane ammoxidation in comparison with propene ammoxidation on the same catalyst. In addition, in propane anaerobic ammoxidation, only surface or subsurface oxygens are involved in the reaction, differently from the case of propene. This suggests that considerable surface reconstruction occurs during propene ammoxidation, whereas this effect is more limited in the case of propane, notwithstanding the G. Centi, S. Perathoner /Applied Catalysis A: General 124 (1995) 317-337 337 formation of surface defects as indicated by infrared results. The real catalyst surface during the catalytic reaction is thus probably different during the catalytic oxidation of the alkane and of the alkene, similarly to that observed for 1 -butene or butadiene and n-butane oxidation over (VO) 2P207 [ 30]. Bologna, V.le Risorgimento 4, 40136 Bologna ,Italy The changes that take place in a vanadium antimonate catalyst during catalytic propane ammoxidation were studied by transient reactivity experiments and infrared spectroscopy. The investigation was focused on both the change in catalytic behaviour of a fresh sample and the change in reactivity with stepwise increases in the concentration of one or more reagents while maintaining the concentration of the other reactants constant. The results obtained show that two main types of modifications are present: (1) A change in the reactivity from the fresh to the activated samples due to the surface formation of a VSbO4 phase by reaction of vanadium and antimony oxides that have not reacted during calcination; this modification leads to formation of carbon oxides and a decrease in the rate of propane depletion as well as a considerable increase in the rate of acrylonitrile formation. (2) A change in the reactivity of the activated sample which is a function of the redox characteristics of the reagent mixture; this modification does not change the rate of propane depletion, but rather only results in differences in the relative selectivity to products. The results also show that (i) in the steady state, the activated catalyst is partially reduced in comparison with the same sample after treatment with oxygen and (ii) the rate of acrylonitrile formation is lower. Infrared results confirm the formation of oxygen vacancies in the catalyst upon interaction with ammonia and propene as well as the presence of these defects in the sample after the catalytic tests.
